title: Ticket #1239: Condor needs more condor_unit_tests
description:
More lower level functions should have unit tests. This ticket collects the ones we add. Please add newer milestones to the top of this list in the Future section, and they will eventually be broken out and given real milestones.

Since this ticket will probably never be completed, just whatever we get done on it gets committed to the development series incrementally, the fixed version is until the end of time.

Milestones

  • Future

  • 09/1/2010 [DONE]
    • StatInfo Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]
    • Directory Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]
    • TmpDir Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]

  • 08/11/2010 [DONE]
    • UserPolicy Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]

  • 08/03/2010 [DONE]
    • Convert these test files to the unit tester [DONE]
      • test_locks.cpp [DONE]
      • test_condor_arglist.cpp [DONE]
      • test_iso_dates.cpp [DONE]

  • 06/30/2010 [DONE]
    • Fix unit test driver [DONE]
      • The success exclamation and return value should be combined. See ticket #1417. [DONE]
      • Convert driver internals to STL so we don't have to declare num of tests. See check-in [18289]. [DONE]
      • Output should include actual test function name with preproccessor magic. [STALLED]
      • One can run 1,..,N specific tests or a set of tests. [DONE]
    • Env Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]

  • 06/09/2010 [DONE]
    • Old ClassAds [DONE]
      • Convert previous test program into unit tests. [DONE]

  • 05/04/2010 [DONE]
    • StringList Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All operator overloads [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]

  • 04/26/2010 [DONE]
    • FlattenAndInline in new ClassAds [DONE]
      • Verify that resulting expressions are semantically equivalent. [DONE]

  • 03/19/2010 [DONE]
    • MyString Object [DONE]
      • All constructors [DONE]
      • All operator overloads [DONE]
      • All methods [DONE]
      • In review and fix status [DONE]
      • Making tickets for bugs found. [DONE]

  • 02/19/2010 [DONE]
    • condor_dirname, condor_basename, fullpath [DONE]
      • coalesced previous test program into unit tests. [DONE]

  • 02/14/2010 [DONE]
    • strupr, strlwr [DONE]
remarks:
2010-Mar-15 16:39:35 by psilord:
psilord's review of the MyString Work: 

General style comments
----------------------

1. In C, two strings next to each other get concatenated by the compiler
automatically. This allows you to change something like this:

    e.emit_test("Does the = operator work correctly when an empty MyString gets assigned a non empty MyString?");

    into the much more readable this:

    e.emit_test("Does the = operator work correctly when an empty MyString "
                "gets assigned a non empty MyString?");

You should use this idiom more and not have any strings of program text
go beyond 80 characters.

2. When a unit test discovers a true bug, don't fix the bug, but write
up a public ticket for it in git trac. Write the test how it is supposed to
work, but leave it commented out in the setting of it into the function_driver.
We may fix the function driver to notice "skipped" or "buggy" tests and
emit them at the end.

Be VERY CAREFUL to ensure that you don't enshrine bugs in the API you
are testing into the test suite. If I do 1 + 2 and get "periwinkle"
as an answer, that is not correct! Don't just assume it is correct because the
system gave you that answer. Of course, we might be relying on that answer
somewhere in Condor, but that is out of your scope for now. :) If it doesn't
make sense, it is most likely wrong. Of course, if any tests cause segfault
ot other horrible thing like that, that is in instant git trac ticket.

Fixes
-----

In function:

copy_constructor
    Rename to copy_constructor_value_check.

    Add a new function called copy_constructor_pointer_check
    which does the same procedure as copy_constructor_value_check,
    but checks only that the pointers returns by one.Value() and
    two.Value() are in fact different.

set_char_last
    This test doesn't test what the emit_test function states and due to
    that it passes with a false positive. Please fix.

random_string_many_chars
    This test doesn't test that the randomly generated string only contained
    characters from the set in question.

    // put into the little utility file for the unit tests.
    int all_str_are_picks(MyString &str, char *picks)
    {
        int i;

        for(i = 0; i < str.Length(); i++) {
            if (strchr(picks, (int)str[i]) == NULL)
                return FALSE;
            }
        }

        return TRUE;
    }

    You'd call it like:
        all_set_is_picks(rnd, "0123456789");

    Most of your random string tests and the function random_string_hex will
    benefit from it.

random_string_negative_length
    User the e.emit_problem function for your Fails comment note. This allows
    it to showup in the resultant output.

equals_operator_my_string_empty_non_empty
    The boolean test doesn't makes sense.dd

concatenation_my_string_itself
    This test looks very wrong, are you stating that

    MyString a("foo")
    a += a;

    and then a is equal to "foo"?

    You expect "foo" in the expected_header and if a.Value() !=
    "foo" it would be an error. I would expect a.Value() to be
    "foofoo" and so != "foo" and it would have been marked an error. So
    the output of your unit tests should have shown at least one error.

    If what I believe is not the case, then it seems MyString has
    a bad bug to me!

    I realize that unit testing is difficult, but ultimately, one must ask
    if the answer you are computing makes sense!

concatenation_char_null
    The note of this test should be an e.emit_problem header.
    Also, this looks like a bug as well. :)

concatenation_int_large
    For this test, use INT_MAX

concatenation_int_small
    For this test, use INT_MIN

concatenation_uint_large
    For this test, use UINT_MAX

concatenation_long_large
    For this test, use LONG_MAX
    The test of this should do a strcmp against a.Value() and
    char buf[1024];
    sprint(buf, "%s%d", "foo", LONG_MAX);
    if (a.Value() != buf) { ... }

    the reason is because LONG_MAX changes depending upon if you
    are on a 32-bit or 64-bit OS. I might propogate this sprintf
    idea to the similar functions above.

concatenation_long_small
    For this test, use LONG_MIN

hash_empty
hash_non_empty
    This is hard to test because 0 to UINT_MAX are all valid numbers and
    the hash function is a black box. For example, the hash funciton
    could return 0 for *everything* asked of it. It'd be a pretty bad hash
    function to have, but it would be mathematically legal. These two are
    ok as they stands, but there should be a e.emit_comment for both of them
    explaining the situation.

find_empty
    That test looks like it exposes a bug in MyString. Given the description
    of find, if find is passed a "", then it should return 0. But here it
    returns -1. I'd say this is another bug.

vsprintf_empty
vsprintf_non_empty
vsprintf_return_true
vsprintf_cat_empty
vsprintf_cat_non_empty
    Memory is leaked in these tests. I might have missed some, so search for
    'new' and similar things which allocate memory, like strdup, or Strdup,
    etc.

vsprintfHelper
vsprintf_catHelper
    Should go to the utils file.

append_to_list_string_non_empty_empty
append_to_list_mystring_non_empty_empty
    Appending an empty string to a mystring in reality appends a comma to it?
    I'd definitely mark that as a problem, and a probable bug.
    Especially since append_to_list_mystring_empty_empty or
    append_to_list_mystring_empty_non_empty didn't do the same
    behavior with an empty string.

read_line_null_file
sensitive_string_equality_default_constructor
sensitive_string_hash_function_empty
    Yikes! That's a bad bug and a git trac ticket to say the least!
